awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Impact of Confinement on the Dynamics of Entangled Chains
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The variety and flexible properties of plastic materials (polymers) has changed our lives. The emergence of particles with a size as tiny as a billionth of a meter (nanoparticles) can provide even more flexible and stronger materials with superior properties as billions of these particles can be incorporated into polymers to yield nanocomposite materials.  Modern chemistry can modify these nanoparticles at the molecular level, which leads to a substantial impact on their material behavior, often with unknown and novel properties. The challenge is to develop a relationship between molecular manipulations and macroscopic properties. This project approaches this task by controlling and varying the spatial distribution of the nanoparticles and by modifying the polymer molecules attached to the surfaces of these particles. The effects of nanoparticle confinement under these conditions will then be studied using advanced experimental techniques.  The project includes the understanding of the relationship between mechanical properties of the nanocomposite materials and the spatial distribution of the nanoparticles, as well as the theoretical description at the molecular length-scale.  This research is also integrated with education of students and exposing them to a variety of advanced experimental techniques.



TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

The effects imposed by nanoconfinement on polymer melts will be studied in this research.  Emphasis will be on the manipulation of the chain dynamics by nanoparticle dispersion, surfaces, and the influence of chains grafted to surfaces. The current understanding is limited by knowledge gaps, which include a missing theoretical understanding of chain dynamics and how to distinguish effects of the particle dispersion and polymer chains. A holistic approach involving small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), dielectric spectroscopy (DS), and rheology, will be used to develop a theory based on recent progress to simultaneously describe the dielectric properties and rheology of polymer melts. Composites of NTPs (tethered chains on nanoparticles) dispersed in polymer matrices will be studied. The dispersion of the NTPs can be controlled by the grafting density, the molecular weight of free chains, and the corresponding characteristics of the NTPs. The static structure factor by SAXS can be used to obtain a phase map of systems with agglomerated and non-agglomerated particles, and to provide information on the length-scale of the confinement. The influence of the additional confinement imposed by nanoparticles on the chain dynamics will be explored, together with a change of the tube diameter of the polymer caused by surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Every day we are using numerous man-made products silently fulfilling their intended purposes. When we compare modern products with earlier versions the progress is particularly visible. Plastic based composites are examples of lightweight materials but stronger than aluminum. However, comparing two product generations, progress is often hard to see. A typical example is a car tire, which has improved tremendously over the past 50 years. Instead, the most recent 5 years show no substantial change. The key to a faster development is understanding of the molecular processes that govern the behavior of materials.

More precisely, material behavior is determined by the motion of the molecules. Basic understanding of the molecular motion is the key to speed-up the development of new materials, creating better materials with additional functions for a better future.

Intellectual Merit

Key for faster development and better materials are understanding and modeling of experimental results, but also to produce materials of higher quality for basic research. This project accomplished all these objectives. It used a technique called dielectric spectroscopy which allows to measure the molecular dynamics in polymers. Many molecules contribute and we discovered a principle that allows to determine the speed of molecules, even if only partial information is available. Due to the project, we know how the molecular composition determines the experimental results on the molecular motion. These results can be used to advance the understanding of composite materials, like the mentioned lightweight materials. The project demonstrated that in mixtures of hard and soft materials, the hard component changes the motion of the soft material. This process depends on the mixing ratios because these allow to control the distances at the molecular scale.

Broader Impacts

This project used generic mathematical principles to derive results, which have been exemplified with dielectric spectroscopy but are generally valid for different techniques and a variety of processes that exist at the molecular level. The results of this project help the researchers in this area to determine speed of molecules more accurately, designed for cases when only incomplete information is available in experimental data. It can be used with a variety of materials and techniques, e.g., with batteries and fuel cells.  

Factories produce a large number of identical items. Researchers typically produce only a few handmade samples. The process of producing these samples is usually time consuming and the quality of the products fluctuate and highly depend on the skill of the individual attempt. We developed an automatic extruder for use in laboratories. This extruder can be built with materials that are typically available in science laboratories. In addition, the process of building this small device has a very positive outcome on students that learn how a certain device helps projects toward the future. For example, the extruder can be used for very small hollow capsules that are likely to boost the efficacy of the next generation of drug delivery systems. The key is that researchers do have materials that have a higher accuracy than man made products, the products do not longer depend on the own skill level, and also the number of samples that can be prepared is much higher.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Gerald Schneider
